questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency.
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know,

  • The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec.
  • The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time.
  • The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction.

Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. 

As paper speed is 1000mm/sec,

Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. 

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz.

Tetanization

The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. 

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

questions.text: The oxygen carrying capacity of a 18 year old boy with haemoglobin of 14g/dl is
questions.solution:
The oxygen carrying capacity of a boy with haemoglobin 14g/dl is 18.

When blood is saturated with 100% O2, the haemoglobin is also 100% saturated and each gram of normal haemoglobin contains 1.39 mL of O2.

However, blood normally contains some inactive haemoglobin derivatives, and the measured value in vivo is thus slightly lower hence, each gram of haemoglobin in vivo contains 1.31 mL of O2 (Hufner’s constant).

According to the above question, when Hb=14g/dl, O2= 1.31*14= 18.34 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve

  • Demonstrates a progressive increase in the percentage of haemoglobin bound with oxygen as blood Po2 increases, which is called the percent saturation of haemoglobin.
  • Blood leaving the lungs and entering the systemic arteries usually has a Po2 of about 95 mm Hg, the usual oxygen saturation of systemic arterial blood averages 97 per cent.
  • Conversely, in normal venous blood returning from the peripheral tissues, the Po2 is about 40 mm Hg, and the saturation of haemoglobin averages 75 per cent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with respiratory volume of 500 mL. The intraplueral pressure measured -4 before inspiration and -8 at the end of inspiration. The pulmonary compliance of the patient is
questions.solution:
Pulmonary compliance of this patient is 125 mL/cm of H2O.

Compliance is developed due to the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the Ptr curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP).

Compliance = Change in lung volume / Change in pressure

Compliance = 500/4

Compliance = 125 ml/cm H20

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to _________

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ sense changes in muscle tension.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension in a contracted muscle is significantly elevated, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to:

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in conc. of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.solution:
The difference between the inflation and the deflation paths is called hysteresis.

It exists because a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway, due to a deficit of surfactant at the air-water interface, than to keep an open airway from closing, as then it has abundant surfactant.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.

The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

A "reverse" Bainbridge reflex has been proposed to explain the decreases in heart rate observed under conditions in which venous return is reduced, such as during spinal and epidural anesthesia, controlled hypotension, and severe hemorrhage.

Physiology of blood pressure regulation is an important topic as it is being frequently asked in both AIIMS and NEET examination.

questions.text: Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of
questions.solution:
Feed forward control system is employed during regulation of temperature.

Feed forward control

There is a control system in our body when no stimulus is required but still the system anticipates and makes corrective changes.

Such a system is called Feed forward or Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

Examples include

  • Temperature control – Thermoregulatory responses are initiated by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature have succeeded in changing the body’s core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Just thinking about food increases gastric acid production
  • Thinking about exercise itself increases heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Role of cerebellum in motor coordination

questions.text: Cellular junctions present in a cardiac muscle are all except:
questions.solution:
Zonula occludens is the other name for the tight junction. It is absent in a cardiac muscle.

Cardiac muscle cells are connected by Fascia adherens (a structural analog of zonula adherens), Gap junctions and Macula adherens.                                                                       

Cardiac muscle fibers are made up of many individual cells connected in series and parallel to one another. The areas where the end of one muscle fiber abuts on another are called intercalated disks. At each intercalated disc, the plasma membrane fuses with one another forming gap junction which provides low resistance bridges for the spread of excitation from one fiber to another permitting the cardiac muscle to function as a syncytium.

According to an update in Robbins and Cotran 10th edition, complexes that mediate the tight junctions are composed of transmembrane proteins including claudin and tight junction-associated MARVEL protein (TAMP) families. These connect to a host of an intracellular adaptor and scaffolding proteins, including the three members of the zonula occludens protein family (ZO-1, ZO-2, ZO-3) and cingulin.

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except:

choices.text: Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.solution:
Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries.

Efferent arteriolar constriction has a biphasic response on GFR depending on the severity of resistance.

Moderate efferent arteriolar constriction causes increased glomerular hydrostatic pressure and slightly increased GFR. 

However, in cases of severe efferent arteriolar constriction (more than threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the renal blood flow is significantly reduced. This results in increased plasma protein concentration, thereby increasing the glomerular colloid oncotic pressure. As the increase in colloid oncotic pressure exceeds the increase in hydrostatic pressure, the net force for filtration decreases, resulting in decreased GFR.

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to:

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.solution:
Absolute refractory period is due to closure of inactive gates of sodium channel.

Voltage-gated sodium channels have 3 states that you can find them in. They can either be closed, open, or inactive.

When the stimulus causes activation of the open gates, sodium rushes into the cell causing the membrane potential to become more positive. After 0.5 to 1 millisecond, the inactive gate automatically closes and no stimulus, no matter how strong, can excite the nerve. This is called the absolute refractory period.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are three permeable ions. X = -50 and Y = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic transfer, what is the value of Z?
questions.solution:
No net electro genic transfer at RMP means X + Y + Z = 0

Since X = -50 and Y = -30, then Z must be +80 since (-80 +80 = 0)

questions.text: Slow waves are generated by:
questions.solution:
The interstitial cells of Cajal undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that peri­odically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that generate slow-wave activity.

Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.

In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

The slow waves usually do not by themselves cause muscle contraction in most parts of the gastrointestinal tract, except perhaps in the stomach. Instead, they mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction.

Note: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

questions.text: A patient has a ​blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

Calculation:

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 90 ml/min
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

                               = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml
                               = 180 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)

  = 180-150 mg/min
  = 30 mg/min

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.solution:
Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle?
questions.solution:
Alpha actinin is the constituent of the marked area.

The image depicts sarcomere and the arrow points towards Z-line. Alpha actinin binds actin to Z-lines.

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

The thick filaments, which are about twice the diameter of the thin filaments, are made up of myosin, which are lined to form A bands; the thin filaments are made up of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin. The array of thin filaments extends out of the A band and into the less dense staining I bands.

The lighter H bands in the center of the A bands are the regions where, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.  The Z lines allow for anchoring of the thin filaments.

Actinin, titin and desmin are additional structural proteins.Titin connects Z-lines to the M line and provides the scaffolding to the sarcomere.  Desmin adds structure to Z-lines by connecting Z-line to plasma membrane.


Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second best answer.

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by:

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling.

A fourth sound is heard immediately before the first sound when atrial pressure is high or the ventricle is stiff in conditions such as ventricular hypertrophy. It is due to ventricular filling and is rarely heard in normal adults.

questions.text: “a” wave on JVP is for
questions.solution:
"a" wave in JVP represents atrial contraction.

Waves of JVP :

  • a- atrial systole pushing the blood to the ventricles.
  • c- isovolumetric contraction of ventricles causing the tricuspid valve to bulge.
  • x'- fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pull of valve leaflets.
  • v- venous filling which creates an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y- passive filling of ventricles by a passive flow of the blood from the right atrium.

questions.text: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and both follow linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B
questions.solution:
The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law :

Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: 

  • Pressure difference: directly proportional
  • Viscosity: inversely proportional
  • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power
  • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional

Here, the radius is doubled so the flow increases by 2 to the power of 4 = 16. 

the length of the vessel is also doubled, so the flow decreases by half (÷2) = 8

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary dancing movements of his right hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever. What constitutes the ganglia involved in the presenting complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sydenham's chorea, a complication of rheumatic fever. The choreic movements are caused by the destruction of D2 neurons of the striatum. The neostriatum consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen.

The image given below shows Sydenham's chorea in a patient.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen
